scenes.location: DEERFIELD HOME HANK AND JOAN'S BEDROOM
characters: AT THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: a man's voice, small, filtered by great distance:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad?... Dad?

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can hardly hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start very close on a phone and Hank's ear.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL VASQUEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (phone filter) I said your son has gone AWOL.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (confused) My son is in Iraq. Widen to see HANK DEERFIELD cradling the phone, sitting o the edge of his bed. You don't have to ask if Hank has se war, he speaks with the confidence of someone who has bee to hell and mapped the terrain. He keeps himself in shape and is not a man who is often caught off guard, which mak his confusion that much more troubling.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL VASQUEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your son was in Iraq, sir. His unit arrived stateside four days ago.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Soldier, if my son was back I would sure as hell know about it. JOAN DEERFIELD, Hank's wife, enters to check what's going on. Joan's a good looking woman, younger than Hank.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL VASQUEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir, Sergeant Carnelli asked me to tell you your son has until Sunday to get back to the base, or he'll be listed as absent. I'm sorry, I have another call. CLICK. Hank hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Who was that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Some horse's ass. Did Mike email you?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Why on earth would he do that? He knows I can't read the darn things.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (exiting) You really should have someone show you sometime.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (calling after him) Sarcasm is not your most endearing quality, Hank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank's desk sits in the corner of an unfinished attic roo Hank checks his answering machine, no messages. He taps t older model laptop computer on his desk; the black screen disappears, revealing his email program: one message -- someone looking for a missing weigh bill. Hank picks up t phone and presses an autodial number.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is Mike, leave a message and if I ever get a signal I'll call you back. Beep.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hey, Mike, it's your old man. Heard you're back. Give me a ring when you get a chance. Hank hangs up, considers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theirs is a modest two bedroom home lying a front-yard's distance off the highway. An ancient but well maintained dump truck sits at the back of a long gravel drive, front end jacked up. The truck door reads Deerfield Hauling. Hank slides out from under the truck with a tie rod and w in his hand. He drops the rod into the box of his 1989 Fo F150 pickup, puts his wrench in the tool chest and pulls his coveralls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the pickup pulls out of the drive we widen to see the rows of identical houses lining the highway, most of them proudly displaying American flags. Welcome to the town of Munroe, Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank waits, the busted tie rod on the counter. A TV in th corner plays a press conference about the state of the wa STU, the 60ish salesman, returns with a new rod.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You're sure this one will fit.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: You gotta trust somebody sometime, Hank. (re: TV) Bet Mike will have some stories to tell, won't he? Course now they can see at night and shoot through concrete walls, almost makes you sorry for the ragheads. Big difference from our day.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What day was that?

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: ...What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Stu, unless I'm mistaken, the only action you saw was Kent State. Shot a school boy, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: ...That was a riot, and I didn't kill anybody.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's what I heard. Hank takes the tie rod and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank steps out of the PARTS STORE and gets into his picku He slows as he passes the local high school, noticing... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: Kids entering don't notice the American flag flying upsid down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank enters to be greeted by LENORE, the cheerful receptionist. The flag is clearly visible from the window

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Why hello there.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm Hank Deerfield.

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Mike's dad, I know that. You know we are all just so proud of Mike and our other boys serving their country...and girls...did you know Cheri Michaels is flying a helicopter? Flunked Drivers Ed and they let her fly a whirlybird.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Miss...

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Lenore.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Lenore. Have you looked out your window this morning?

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: This window right here?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: This window right here. Do you see anything odd? The flag?... (nothing) See how it's flying upside down?

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Oh, gosh, I didn't notice that. Oh dear. Well don't you worry, I will have that put right first thing in the morning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It is the morning.

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: We just get so busy here.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Lenore, do you happen to know what it means, a flag flying upside down?

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: That someone's died?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: --See, I always get that wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: --That's flying at half mast.

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Could mean that the person putting it up wasn't paying a lot of attention. She laughs at her own joke, as she often does.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, it could. But it doesn't. Who raises the flag every morning, the principal?

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Oh, good gosh no, he comes running in about one minute before nine; no it's Juan, our janitor.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (this is getting worse by the second) The janitor raises the flag. who takes it down at night?

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Juan.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Right. So, why don't we ask Juan to fix it right now? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Oh, I couldn't do that. He has so much to do; you know they laid off all the other janitorial staff, with cutbacks and such, he can hardly keep up as it is.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Fine. Then I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm afraid I can't let you handle school property; it's an insurance issue.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: A flag is not school property. All flags are property of the US government, who loan them to us under the promise that we treat them with respect.

dialogues.speaker: LENORE
dialogues.text: No, I'm pretty sure we bought that one. I know because I had to order it when we threw the old one in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: In the trash. Listen, before I get myself in a lot trouble, why don't you just tell me where to find Juan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flooded, Hank stands in an inch of brown water. JUAN drop his pipe wrench back into his toolkit on the sink. Juan h a Mayan face and speaks with the accent of an immigrant.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Now? Hank slips him a ten dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'd really appreciate it. Juan shrugs and heads out, wiping his hands. Hank takes a long look at the mess before exiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juan reattaches the flag. Hank snags the tip just before hits the grass.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You don't let it touch the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: El Salvador.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What's your flag look like?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: A flag.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know what it means when a flag is hung upside down? (he doesn't) It's an international distress signal.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No shit. It means we are in a whole lot of trouble, so come save our ass, cause we haven't got a prayer in hell of saving ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: It says a lot.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yes, it does. So, you know how to do it now?

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Good. Juan looks up at the flag flying. Hank walks to his truck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan watches from the kitchen window. Out in the drive, Hank lies under his dump truck, smacking the rod with a mallet. He curses it and rises.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (passing the kitchen) Anyone call?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: No. Joan watches him tread upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings in Hank's ear, until:

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fort Rudd, how may I direct your call?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: First Sgt. Arnold Bickman, Criminal Investigations Division.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry, sir, I have no one by that name on base.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thank you. Hank hangs up, swivels in his chair and sees Joan standin in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You going to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank opens his top drawer, removes three neatly folded pa of underwear, socks, three white undershirts. He tucks th into a small zip bag and opens his second drawer, removes three starched white cotton shirts and a shoe shine kit.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I want to go with you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: If he's holed up somewhere celebrating, the last thing he needs is his mother walking in on him. I'll call you when I get there tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It's a two day drive.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: For some people. He kisses her on the forehead, puts his laptop under his and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copies of Soldier of Fortune share the shelves with sport memorabilia and snapshots of Mike and his buddies in Bosn (circa 2001) and Iraq (2003). Hank fingers an autographed football, puts it back and slips a photo of Mike in his d uniform out of the frame. He pockets it and heads out, flicking off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup speeds along, passing a car or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank does what he does best, drive. An oncoming big rig blinds him with its high beams. Hank squints.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dad? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank WAKES with a start. He hears tapping. Hank looks to his driver's side window and is surprised to see...

dialogues.speaker: A FIERCE-LOOKING CHOLO
dialogues.text: standing at the open window, chewing gum. Tattoos, scarre face, someone you would cross the street to avoid. Hank tries not to react. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHOLO
dialogues.text: How ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Good. You?

dialogues.speaker: CHOLO
dialogues.text: Very good. You got a light? Hank pushes in his cigarette lighter and they wait. Tense It pops out. Hank hands it to him and the Cholo lights hi smoke.

dialogues.speaker: CHOLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. And he walks back to his junker car, where Hank sees evid of someone else sleeping in the back seat. A small Americ flag flies clipped to the window. Several other vehicles are parked in this REST STOP off t interstate, mostly trucks and campers. Out in the patch of grass a young boy kicks a soccer ball around while his parents sleep.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Dad?.... Dad! Hank smiles to himself, grabs his bag and opens his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank puts away his shaving kit, buttons the cuffs of his newly pressed cotton shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup drifts up to the guard kiosk and Hank hands th GUARD his ID - RETIRED MILITARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank waits. SERGEANT FIRST CLASS DAN CARNELLI steps out.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: Sgt. Deerfield?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hank. Thanks for seeing me, I know you're busy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: (walking him in) You should have let me know you were coming; I would have cleared some time. Bet the base has changed a lot since your day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank and Sgt. Carnelli sit. A corporal brings in coffee.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What about his buddies?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: We asked, of course. (re: coffee) Thanks. (to Hank) A lot of men are just coming back today from a 72. I don't want you to think I'm not concerned, but where these boys have been, it's a miracle more of them don't blow outta here for a few days. For the last eighteen months they couldn't drink, couldn't even flirt with a woman. They touch down, the first thing they do is find a bar and a girl. I expect your son will come stumbling in looking for a shot of penicillin.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: ...You mind if I had a look at his quarters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men come and go in their Green BDUs. Sgt. Carnelli and Ha weave through the men. Carnelli spots CORPORAL STEVE PENN 22, calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: Penning.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Yes, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: This is Specialist Deerfield's father. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Steve Penning, good to meet you, sir. Have you heard from Mike?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: Mr. Deerfield wants to take a look at his son's quarters.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: (to Hank) Certainly, sir. Shortcut is through here. (leads them) Mike and I go back to Bosnia, he sure told me enough stories about you. He hasn't called or anything?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You find that surprising?

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: You'd know better than me, sir, but I recall Mike showing up for roll call with a collarbone sticking through his skin. Penning spots two soldiers ahead watching a foosball game Calls tot Meet SPECI hem:

dialogues.speaker: PENNING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Long, Ortiez. This is Doc's dad. ALIST ENNIS LONG, 22 and PRIVATE ROBERT ORTIEZ, Mexican American, same age.

dialogues.speaker: LONG
dialogues.text: Honor to meet you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Doc?

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: A nickname we gave him, made no sense. (points to door ahead) That's Mike's room there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Carnelli goes ahead and knocks, then reaches for his ring keys. Hank hangs back with Ortiez and Long.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You boys have any idea where Mike could be?

dialogues.speaker: LONG
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: Must be one hell of a woman. Something makes Hank take a beat before responding. For some reason he doesn't like Ortiez.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LONG
dialogues.text: Good meeting you, sir. Suddenly Mike's door opens from inside, revealing SPECIAL GORDON BONNER, bare-chested. He just stares at them.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: (taken aback) This is Specialist Deerfield's dad, we've come to look at his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: (stepping back) Then you don't need a key. Somebody took a boot to it yesterday. Carnelli checks the cracked door frame as Hank steps in.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: You report this to the CQ?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Yes, Sergeant. Sorry, thought you were somebody trying to steal stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonner retreats into the adjoining bathroom. Through it, Hank sees a bedroom beyond. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Your room?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Yeah. (re: bed near the wall) That's Mike's bunk there. Bonner goes back to his room to finish dressing. Hank loo around Mike's small room: two single beds, small desks, bedside tables and lamps.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (re: second bed) Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: We lost a man. Hank nods. He opens the closet; all his son's clothes are still there. He searches the top shelf, then pulls a duff bag out of the bottom; checks the contents.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's your duffel, right?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: Tried to convince him to use the one he was issued, it was like talking to a wall. Hank walks to the small bureau, opens it, sees the very n folded, neatly pressed t-shirts and shirts squared away i the drawer. Hank suddenly stops and looks around the room just now noticing something by its absence.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: There are no photographs.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Mike's always taking pictures, emailing them to me. I don't see any photographs. Or a camera.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLT
dialogues.text: You saw the door. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Property theft is a real problem. I guess that hasn't changed since your stint.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No. Hank steps to Mike's bedside table. He fingers open the Bible lying on it. The inside leaf is stamped: Courtesy o Chaplain Services. He pulls open the drawer and notices a battered cell phone hiding amongst the junk.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: Bible) Mind if I take this? His mother gave it to him. I left mine at home. As he picks up the Bible with his right hand he smoothly palms the cell phone with his left and slips it into his pocket. He looks to the bathroom door and notices Bonner, looking away, tucking in his shirt. Did he see him palm t cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: I'd like to, but I can't let you remove anything.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I understand. He puts the Bible back on the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank signs out and walks off toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Sergeant Deerfield? Hank turns to see Penning trotting up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hank.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Before he left for Iraq, Mike was seeing a girl: her name was Jennifer Lopez. We teased him about dating J Lo.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know where I could find her? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'll ask around.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thank you. Hank turns and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young SALESPERSON replaces the battery in Mike's phone.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: This thing's been around some intense heat.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's been in Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: That could do it. (tries power, nothing) Sorry, it's dead. But I can give you a new phone with more features with a two year contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank stands next to the open door of a panel van. Inside GABRIEL, a cell phone technician sits at a bench with a computer and equipment. He plugs the phone in under:

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I need any phone numbers in memory. Garbled information comes up on the computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: This is seriously fried. (searching) Address book. You got numbers for Barracks, Burgers, Chicken, Jenn--

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Give me that one. The technician points to the screen. Hank points to the guy's cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Sure. Hank picks it up and dials the number as the technician continues to work. Hank hears:

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED MESSAGE
dialogues.text: The number you have dialed is no longer -- Hank snaps it closed.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Mom, Pizza, TD's and Ted.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: TD's?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Local joint. Coulda been more but that's all that's left.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thanks. How much? Hank digs for his wallet. The technician studies the scre

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You want the media? This catches Hank off guard - what media?

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: The phone tech clicks on an icon and a VIDEO CLIP PLAYS. There's electronic drop out and only sporadic sound, but it's Mike's squad -- BONNER, PENNING, LONG, ORTIEZ, drivi on the road to Baghdad, singing a marching song we only h bits of. The camera pans to the windshield, where we see the convo of assault vehicles. Smoldering carcasses and Iraqi tanks trucks and civilian automobiles line their route. Mike pushes the camera out the window and gets a shot of large FLAG mounted on a pole fixed to the High Back Humve flapping in the wind. He pulls the camera back in and the image freezes on a shot of Mike. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That your son?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That's Mike.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Sure as hell glad they didn't get me.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That feeling is probably mutual. Any more?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: (taps more keys) Yeah, but they're real corrupted. If you want 'em I got a program at home that might be able to pull them off, but it's real slow. Charge you a hundred flat?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (digs out wallet) Can you email them to me?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (handing him $100) Where's TD's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naked women twirl on poles to unbearably loud RAP MUSIC. The place is jammed with off duty soldiers. The BOUNCER points to the bar. Hank squeezes through the crowd and fi the BARTENDER. He pulls out Mike's photo and shouts to be heard:

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm looking for my son! The bartender nods towards the crowd: "good luck." Hank steps deeper into the club, scans the faces. He's quickly overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he leaves, Hank glances over to a small group of men standing between two cars. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Three are Hispanic gangbanger types, two are soldiers out uniform that look to be scoring some drugs. The most dangerous-looking gangbanger eyeballs Hank until he reach his pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign boasts FREE INTERNET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank checks in.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: You need a wake up call?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I've been waking up without an alarm every morning at four a.m. for the past forty years; I think I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: You want to make the wake up calls? Hank smiles and heads for his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Hank checks his email. His In Box is empty. - Hank runs his fingers down the crease of his pants and lays them flat between his mattress and box spring. - He polishes his shoes and squares them beside the bed. - He calls his wife. As he speaks, Hank clicks through a folder of photos his son emailed from Iraq, shots of him his buddies.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But why would he leave without telling us?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'll ask him when I see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan sits on the edge of the bed; speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hank? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'll find him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: ...Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank hangs up. Hank stops on a photo that seems to troubl him, we don't see it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COPY PLACE
dialogues.text: Quiet this time of night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COPY PLACE
dialogues.text: Hank stands at the self-serve color printer as Mike's pho spit out. Most of them are just snaps of him and his budd One of them is different -- Hank picks it up. It's a photo of what might be a BODY LYING ON THE SHOULDE OF A ROAD, taken from a distance. The image is chilling.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You gotta get me out of here, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank wakes in darkness, disoriented. The clock reads 3:58 AM. He switches on the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Hank snaps open the curtains. - He pulls his bed sheets so tight you could bounce a coi off them, and folds an impossibly sharp corner. - A maid pushes her cart along the walkway. Through his bedroom window, Hank's computer comes to life. Hank check his email: no new messages. - He pulls a crisp cotton shirt from his overnight bag. - He takes the local phone book from the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first rays hit the Imperial Motel sign. Hank steps in the coffee shop next door carrying the phone book.  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leafs through the phone book; several pages of LOPEZes and a large number of Jennifers or initial "J."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank at the payphone, the phone book propped on the shelf lots of pen lines scratching off highlighted numbers. CNN coverage of last night's presidential press conference pl on the TV in the background.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Morning, is this Jennifer Lopez? Do you speak English?... (hangs up, tries next) Hello, I'm looking for Jennifer Lopez. (beat) Beverly Hills, thanks very much. Hank hangs up. Considers. Flips through the book until he finds a listing for ARNOLD BICKMAN. He dials.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Arnold Bickman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out through the glass, we see a man who looks lik he'd be an ARNOLD BICKMAN get out of his camper and limp towards the restaurant like a man who needs a new hip. He Hank's age, but looks ten years older. Unlike Hank, Arnol is no longer "fighting trim." Hank waves him over from hi booth. They shake hands heartily.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: My God. Hank Deerfield.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What the hell you doing at home?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: You just caught us. We're taking off in the camper to visit the grandkids.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I called you at the base -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: The base? Christ, Hank, I retired fourteen years ago.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You did not.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: Almost fifteen. How the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Fine. You want coffee or a piece of pie?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: No, I can't. Helen's waiting in the camper.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (looking) That her? She looks as old as you do. Arnold has to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: You are still the meanest man I ever met. So, what did you do, break an axle and call me for a tow?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No, I was hoping you were still at CID; I wanted a friendly face.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: Neither of your boys in trouble, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: What was the oldest boy's name, Darren?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: David.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: That's right, joined the 82nd Airborne, didn't he? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: Tough sons of bitches. How's he liking it?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: He died. On maneuvers at Fort Bragg. Helicopter crash. Ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry to hear that, Hank. Very sorry. The young one?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Mike. He's regular Army, like his dad. He's in Iraq, doing real well. (beat ) I'm just doing a favor for a neighbor; her boy got in a little trouble. Anybody we know still there?

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: No. All gone. How many times did I call you and say we should get together? Helen HONKS THE HORN. Arnold looks.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: She keeps you on a schedule.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: The kids are expecting us. They slide out of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step up to the door, through which we see Arnold's RV.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: You sure there's nothing I can do?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It was just good to see your old sad bones.

dialogues.speaker: ARNOLD BICKMAN
dialogues.text: I'm gonna call you when we get back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That'd be great. (looking at Helen) Your wife, just how old is she? Arnold laughs and walks off. Hank waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank comes out of a bar, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank sits silhouetted by the motel signs outside his wind as he downloads a video file sent to him by Gabriel, aka "PhoneGuy@Earthlink.Net."

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: Mike plays to the camera, readies to toss a football toa young, ragged Iraqi kid in a Baghdad street.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (into camera) Historic moment, first time this kid has ever caught a real American football. Here we go. He hands the camera phone to GORDON BONNER. Mike throws t ball. The street kid catches it and he and his buddies ru away.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, you run this way! This way! (realizes) Hey, that's my ball you little fucker! We can hear GORDON BONNER laughing. Mike grabs for the ph

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pissed but laughing) Gimme that back. And the screen freezes, end of clip. Hank laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank returns a form to JODIE, the civilian worker wearing headset behind the desk. She gives it a quick glance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JODIE
dialogues.text: Hold please. (to Hank) Your son is in the Army.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: JODIE
dialogues.text: (handing it back) Then you need to see the Military Police.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: They're pretty busy with the war and everything, so I'm trying to check things out myself.

dialogues.speaker: JODIE
dialogues.text: All you can do is file a missing person's report --

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: JODIE
dialogues.text: -- in which case you'll need to see the Military Police.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: How about you let me talk to someone who does more than answer phones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank waits as Detectives come and go. He rises and STEPS INTO THE OFFICE, where he eyes DET. EMILY SANDERS listeni impatiently to a young white woman we will call ANGIE.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand. He loved that dog.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I'm sure he did, ma'am. But the dog bit him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: A dog bites you, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I really don't know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hank tries to get a male detective's attention; gets the brush-off. He and another detective (HODGE and WAYNE) are having too much fun watching Angie deal with her doggie c

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: You tie it up, you give it away, you might even shoot it, but you sure as hell don't pick it up by the throat, wrestle it into the bathroom and drown it in the tub! You don't think there's something seriously wrong with that?!

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Perhaps he thought it was more humane.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: More humane?! It's a Doberman! And he's drowning it right in front of our son, and it's biting him, and I'm screaming for him to stop. Does all this sound humane to you?! Hank tries another passing detective, same result.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Did your husband threaten you or your child with violence?

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: He'd never hurt us, he just needs help.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Then you should ask the VA about counseling.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: You don't think I've been there? He won't go, and he's going to hurt himself, I know it!

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I would like to do something --

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Really? Cause I would say you don't give a crap. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (now pissed and nasty) In fact I do, but crimes against dogs are particularly hard to prosecute. Now I have someone waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Fuck you, lady. And she storms out. Hank takes that as his cue to approac and hand Detective Sanders the missing person's form.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That kind of morning, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (glancing at form) You have to take this to the Military Police.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I'm trying to keep my son out of more trouble. Listen, I know you're busy, but all I need you to do is make a call to his bank, see if he's withdrawn any funds or used his credit card in the last week.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Retired cop or just watch a lot of

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Military Police, retired.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Then you know that the Army has jurisdiction over its personnel. I'm sorry, I hope you find your son.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Listen, I don't know what you think your job is. If it is anything like mine, it was to roll up the drunks, twiddle my thumbs and not ask too many questions. But my son just spent eighteen months bringing democracy to a shithole and serving his country. He deserves better than this. He drops the form and walks out.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking in through the window we see Hank on the phone. H computer screen shows an on-line banking form.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I found his old checkbook.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Is there anything written on it? I need a password.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the bedroom window we see Joan at Mike's desk wit his checkbook, cradling the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: There's nothing on it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Hank hears the sound of email arriving. He minimizes the bank webpage to reveal his email account and an email fro PHONEGUY. He downloads the attachment.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Which do you think it is, Hank: I'm blind or I just don't feel like telling you? Silence. Hank would apologize if he could. Joan knows him well enough to understand that, and not require it.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm worried, Hank. I'm really worried.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: He's a good boy. He'll have a reason.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMPUTER SCREEN
dialogues.text: The image quality is terrible, chunks of video are missin sometimes half the screen is just garbage. But nonetheles we see what Mike saw as his High Back Humvee patrolled th streets of Baghdad in convoy. FLASHES - out the driver's side window, no more friendly faces. People toss jeers, others scurry out of the way. NOW ON SCREEN: The convoy ahead. Spot sheep herded on the side of the road ahead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bonner, look, there's your family. Bonner presents his middle finger to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: . Hank? Hank pauses the video.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'll find him. I'll talk to you tomorrow. And he hangs up and hits play.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Stop screwing around. Bonner slaps the camera out of Mike's hand. It tumbles to the floor and we see Mike askew.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You coulda broke it!

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Stuff it up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Gimme back my goddamn- -

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: (sees something) Son of a bitch. Mike's head snaps to the windshield:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Don't stop! Don't fucking stop!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What do I do?!

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Speed up! Mike stomps on the accelerator and a second later we hear small thud as something hits the grill and then rolls und the vehicle's undercarriage. They drive on in silence. Bonner's hand reaches down and turns off the camera phone (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The screen goes BLACK. The SILENCE is punctured by the so of a sharp inhale as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank wakes, startled. He must have fallen asleep, but he can't recall. He checks his watch: 7 PM. He sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders returns from an interview. Several detectives hus past her, including Hodge and Wayne. She calls after them

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE HODGE
dialogues.text: Don't you worry. If it's an animal- related crime we will call you in. She enters the DETECTIVE SQUAD ROOM. It's empty, just a ringing phone. She walks to her desk as DETECTIVE NUGENT comes out of the men's room, zipping his fly and pulling his coat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: They found body parts out on Mesa Luna Road. (off her sick feeling) Don't think the parts are actually on the road.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: That's comforting, Nugent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank enters. The motel clerk is watching TV; war coverage

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Do you have an iron?

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: People keep stealing them. World's gone crazy.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You have a good hardcover book?  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police vehicles sit on the shoulder, lights flashing. Flashlights sweep the acres of tumbleweed and scrub brush a couple of dozen men search for evidence. Sanders steps to a small clearing, the remains of a fire. Evidence flag mark spots where bones remain. Sanders kneels to inspect charred bone; notes where it was shattered. Behind her, Wayne addresses a uniformed cop.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE WAYNE
dialogues.text: I need more evidence markers.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You got all that we have.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Straighten out some coat hangers and buy Dixie cups to stick on the end of them. (hands cop a bill) And get a receipt.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE WAYNE
dialogues.text: (trudging off) Coyotes had a field day with this one; bones are scattered half a mile. Sanders nods and moves off. Approaching headlights get he attention -- a Military Police vehicle pulls up and parks Two officers step out and survey the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank washes his cotton shirt in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders notices something hidden in the brush. Motions fo a CSI Tech to hand her a coat hanger and a Dixie Cup. Pla it next to:

dialogues.speaker: A SEVERED WRIST AND HAND
dialogues.text: blackened, the fingers and much of the flesh burned away. too.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Sean? The photographer joins her.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank stretches the wet shirt flat over the bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glancing back to the road, Sanders sees her immediate sen Lt. Burke, standing with CHIEF OF POLICE SIMON BUCHWALD, leans on his car. He doesn't look happy to be here. An unmarked CID sedan drifts to a stop and two plain clot Army investigators step out. By his bearing, LT. KIRKLAND is clearly the one in charge. They join the uniformed MPs already on scene, who are standing with Detective Hodge. Sanders has seen this before and knows what is happening. Lt. Kirklander hands a hundred foot tape measure to the M

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: heads toward the police chief and her lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: (to Sanders) Anyone else from the office coming? I could swear we have a couple of secretaries who haven't shown up yet. Detective Hodge grins as he returns from his tete-a-tete with the MPs. In the background the two MPs stretch the measuring tape from the center of the road into the field

dialogues.speaker: LT. BURKE
dialogues.text: Tell me good news, Hodge.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE HODGE
dialogues.text: Looks as if the victim was killed by that fire site, then his body was chopped up and burned. Animals scattered the parts.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: And you're smiling like an idiot because?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE HODGE
dialogues.text: The base bought this field from the city two months ago. City property only extends fifty feet from the center line of the road. Don't think it's our body, Chief. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They look to the field, where one of the MPs is driving a surveyor's stake into the ground at the fifty foot mark. The burn site is well past that mark.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: Hallelujah, let's go home. The Chief gets in his car and drives off. Lt. Burke calls in the troops as more Military Police vehicles arrive.

dialogues.speaker: LT. BURKE
dialogues.text: Wrap it up, fellas, the boys with the shiny buttons are coming in! Sanders notices Lt. Kirklander playfully flip Burke the finger. Burke smiles as he walks off -- it's obvious thes two are buddies. Burke passes Sanders and Kirklander noti her watching. She turns away, Kirklander goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank picks up the hardcover book and runs the sharp edge along the wet shirt to press out the wrinkles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders watches the police move out and the military take over. She gets in her car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank hangs the shirt up on the shower rod and turns off t light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank swings his legs over the edge of the bed. It's still dark. The clock glows 6:17 AM. He looks at it oddly, chec his watch to make sure it's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank lathers with soap and shaves. Sees that he's nicked himself. Hates that. He sticks a dab of paper on the cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheers glow with the early light as Hank makes his be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheers are open now as Hank steps out and into the pa of the MATRONLY ASIAN HOUSEKEEPER with her cart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks into Hank's room, then turns and repeatedly bow her thanks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank eats his usual breakfast, watching the war news on C as he adds items to the list on his neatly written pad. H notices blood smeared on his hand and white cuff and real his neck is bleeding again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank returns to the motel. As he gets to his door, he hea a car door close, sees an army officer in full dress unif approaching. Call him CAPTAIN OSHER.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN OSHER
dialogues.text: Mr. Deerfield? Jim Osher, can I have a word?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Come in, I'll just be a minute. Hank steps into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a wad of toilet paper and holds it to the cut, putting pressure on it for a moment. He tries to focus on that small task and block out the man in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank opens the bathroom door and stops, as he sees: Capta Osher standing at attention, holding a salute. Hank awkwa returns it.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN OSHER
dialogues.text: Sir, I regret to inform you a body was found last night. Upon investigation we believe it to be the remains of your son, Specialist Michael Deerfield. The officer drops his salute.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Right. They'll need me to identify him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN OSHER
dialogues.text: .No, sir. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN OSHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They've determined identity in other ways. I believe partial fingerprints.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What do you mean, partial? What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN OSHER
dialogues.text: I'm not at liberty to say, sir, but someone from--

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I want to see his body. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Det. Sanders sits restlessly at her desk, unable to keep mind on the work before her. She stands and steps away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank rounds the corridor with Lt. Kirklander, who tries o last time.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: Sgt. Deerfield, this isn't necessary and it's not the way you want to remember your son.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Maybe not, but it's the way he left this earth, so I don't see as I have a choice. Kirklander sees Hank won't be dissuaded. An Army MEDICAL EXAMINER in a lab coat approaches. Kirklander nods to him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders hovers in the doorway of a small cubicle, where t police photographer's printer spits out the evening's cri scene photos. Sanders is drawn into the cubicle, mesmerized by the grue color pictures. We intercut Sanders watching these images come out of the printer with the following scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank and Kirklander stand on one side of a large stainles steel table, the Army Medical Examiner on the other. Betw them lie the charred remains. Kirklander watches Hank und (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Working backwards: the carbon patterns show that the body was dismembered before it was burnt. It appears a knife or similar tool was used; but the blade was dull, many of the joints are shattered rather than severed. The burn patterns tell us the dismembered parts were stacked and doused with an accelerant in an attempt to incinerate the body; ridiculous because you need an oven to approach an effective temperature. Which means most of the tissue would have been left intact, so the damage is largely a result of scavengers stripping the bones. (we see the teeth marks) Cause of death is going to take more time to determine, but there's evidence of multiple stab wounds.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: How many wounds?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: With most of the flesh missing we can only count the blows that made impact with a bone.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: How many of those are there? Only now does the medical examiner begin to understand th obvious, that he's telling all this to the corpse's fathe He checks his pad, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: ...Forty-two.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (beat) One knife or several?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police photographer returns to his cubicle, not particularly surprised to see Sanders standing there.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You gonna turn these over to the Army?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Tried to. Said they took their own photos. They didn't say it ina nice way. He drops them into a file and puts them in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirklander and Hank round the corner from the M.E.'s offi

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: If it's all right, I'd like to give you a call tomorrow, before you go home, I have a few questions that--

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Ask them now.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: ...I can check with records and answer some of these things -- I take it your son didn't own a green car?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Mike doesn't own a car.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: A motorist reported seeing a green sedan parked on the shoulder near the field Saturday night. One theory is that this was a car-jacking or robbery gone wrong. There's been a real uptick in gang activity lately.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'd like to see where he died.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, it's still an active crime scene. I'll let you know as soon as you can. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Okay. (silence) What else you want to ask?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: A lot of the deaths we've seen like this have been drug related.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (walks off) Are you asking if Mike was a drug dealer or just an addict?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: I don't want to be asking anything.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know the Army does regular drug tests.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: Not while they're in Iraq. (produces a small hash pipe in an plastic bag) We found this under your son's mattress. It won't go on my report, but why I ask...last month we arrested three soldiers trying to smuggle heroin in from Kuwait. They'd arranged to sell it to a local Mexican gang. I understand Mike spoke some Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You think my son could have been a drug mule because he spoke Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: No, because somebody cut off his hands and his head. Hank turns and walks off. Kirklander watches, sizing him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders pulls on her jacket and heads out. Turning into t hall, she spots Hank on the long wooden bench.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I am so sorry about your son. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Show me.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I need to see where he died.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: It's not our case, the murder occurred on military property.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: But you know where it is.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: There is nothing to see.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Then there shouldn't be a problem with me seeing it. Sanders sees how hard Hank is trying to hide his pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders leans against her blue Ford Taurus in the sickly yellow wash of the streetlight, her car parked the wrong on the gravel shoulder, high beams failing to illuminate much of the field where Hank stands. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You people sure as hell know how to trample a crime scene, I'll give you that. Hank squats where the body was burned and pivots, shining his flashlight at the tumbleweeds and scrub brush.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Suppose you figured it was a good idea to have everyone you ever met park on this shoulder. (beat) If your crime scene boys had known where to dig, they'd have found traces of blood in the gravel here. It's where he was killed.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, you don't see blood, but you know it's there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yes, miss. Just like I see how his body was dragged from here to there.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: That's remarkable. That ground is rock hard, but you see drag marks.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You go to all the trouble of burning a body, you don't think you'd try and cover your path? Hank hands her the flashlight and walks off across the ro toward the parking lot and the gun store on the far side.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Going to use the restroom. Curious now, Sanders takes her flashlight and steps into field. Hank struts across the road. Without looking back:

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You might find it easier to drive around the field. You couldn't do more damage. She throws a look, then shines her flashlight on the grou finally spots a broken base of a tumbleweed -- lifts it a places it aside. She takes another step toward the fire site and finds another broken weed and puts it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank crosses the parking lot and opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders lifts a last tumbleweed out of the way and stops the fire site. She turns and sees the clear, trampled pat of where the body was dragged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank waits. JO ANNE steps up to the counter. She's dresse like she's looking for a man to take her away from here.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hi. I suppose the MPs have been in asking you questions about what happened over in that field. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JO ANNE
dialogues.text: Yes, they have. Terrible thing.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm checking it out for the family. You mind if I ask you if you saw anything going on over there? Her jealous husband, RANDY, approaches to check out Hank.

dialogues.speaker: JO ANNE
dialogues.text: Wished we had, we would've liked to help. We didn't even know what it was when we smelled it, did we, honey? Hank doesn't show that his heart just stopped beating.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: ...How's that?

dialogues.speaker: JO ANNE
dialogues.text: That Sunday morning, when we drove into the parking lot. We just thought somebody'd been barbecuing.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (agreeing) Smelled like burned meat.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thanks. Mind if I use your restroom?

dialogues.speaker: JO ANNE
dialogues.text: Through that door. Show him, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank squats on the floor beside the toilet and lets the h of his son's body being burned overwhelm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Returning to the shoulder, Sanders turns and spots a dog the field, chewing on something. Her stomach tells her wh that something is. She curses silently as she throws a lo across the road; sees Hank coming from the parking lot. Sanders picks up a hand full of pebbles and tosses them t the dog, who balks but quickly returns. She throws a look in Hank's direction, gauges that he hasn't noticed and to another handful in the dog's direction. It barely even lo up this time. Hank arrives and steps to the Taurus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You can tell your MP friends they should be looking for a blue car, not a green one.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Because a blue car under a yellow light looks green, doesn't it? Hank gets in and Sanders looks at her car -- which looks green in this light. Almost angry at herself for not seei the obvious, she opens her door and gets in. She does a U-TURN and DRIVES OFF. HANK watches the dog in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders drops him off.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: It was the least I could do.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'd say that's accurate. And he walks away, leaving her wondering why she even tri to be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest bungalow on the outskirts of town. Sanders enter as her sitter, LEE ANNE, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Lee Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having just been told the news, Joan opens her mouth to c out...but no sound escapes. Her knees won't hold her weig so she slides down the wall to land gracelessly on the fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank sits on the bed, his back to us, the phone to his ea caught in the glow of the passing headlights. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why? Who would do this? He was just a boy. And he was almost home.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm going to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan on the hall phone by the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'll get a plane ticket.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean "no"?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'll bring him home soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I need to see him, Hank. I need to be with Michael.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: He is gone, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I need to be with my boy, Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: There is nothing left.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Joan, for once in your life can you just take my word for something?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: -- For once? For once?! I seem to remember me being the one saying "no" and you saying "it will be good for his character!" Who won that argument, Hank?!

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Mike was the one wanted to join, I sure as hell didn't encourage it! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Like he could ever have felt like a man if he hadn't gone. Both my boys, Hank. You could have left me one. And with that she finally weeps, the sound so piercing an full of pain that it goes right through Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Joan?... Joan, please. (finally) Joan, I can't listen to you cry.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Then don't. She hangs up and sits there, alone on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders lies in bed holding her sleeping son, DAVID. Look at her boy, she can't help but imagine what Hank must fee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank sits on his bed, reading the motel's Bible, hoping t find comfort. His head turns as he hears the SOUND of an email arriving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders tiptoes out and eases the door closed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Door. She eases it back open and looks in, his eyes are still closed. She moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distorted video images appear on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike's buddies huddle beside a building, light playing on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Better hang up, Saddaam could be calling. "Mike, Mike, I give up." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mike pans to show the explosions that light up the night Sky.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATROL
dialogues.text: The squad moves through an alley, checking doorways. Mike and a buddy enter a house. Inside, bodies lie incinerated where they fell.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- really weird, Dad. Their clothing is melted into them, as if heat from the b did the damage. Mike zooms in on a hand with a book, flip through the pages, not even singed. Mike frames the dead man's blackened face. He looks young. Mike presses a brightly colored SKATEBOARD STICKER onto the man's forehe No explanation. The screen FREEZES on that image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A uniformed cop guides a young handcuffed redneck punk na MILLARD, 18, into the chair beside Sanders' desk. Sanders sits in her chair reading a report. She glances up from i eyes the punk, then throws a look to the coffee area, whe Lieutenant Burke stands with Detectives Hodge and Wayne; three pretending not to laugh or look in her direction. Sanders finishes reading the report, stands...

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Stay there. (marches over to Burke) Excuse me, Lieutenant, but I was wondering how I came to be assigned this case.

dialogues.speaker: LT. BURKE
dialogues.text: ...Which case? Hodge and Wayne choke back their laughter.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (re: report) Jacob Ronald Millard, slaughterhouse employee, arrested for torturing chickens.

dialogues.speaker: MILLARD
dialogues.text: (calling across the room) It's no big deal, everybody does it! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Everybody doesn't poke out their eyes, asshole!

dialogues.speaker: MILLARD
dialogues.text: Sure they do.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: MILLARD
dialogues.text: My boss just doesn't want me humping his daughter!

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (to Millard) Now we are shocked beyond words.

dialogues.speaker: LT. BURKE
dialogues.text: You see the way you can draw information out of people? People just like you, Emily. That's how you got promoted from traffic to the detective squad, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry??

dialogues.speaker: LT. BURKE
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be. If Wayne and Hodge could have fucked their way into the squad, they would have, too.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE HODGE
dialogues.text: Wayne would have. One of us needs to know what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Ah. See, that's what concerns me. Having fucked my way into this job, I may not be qualified to piece together this complex of a crime. I mean, take the murder site; I would have never come to the conclusion that that soldier had been killed on Army property. I would have been fooled by the signs of struggle on the shoulder of the road. And that trail of broken brush leading from there to where he was burned would have made me think he was killed in our jurisdiction and moved because (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the killers didn't think it smart to chop him up right under a bright streetlight. I would have totally misread the crime scene. Silence. Nugent, sitting nearby, appreciates the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders stands in front of Chief's desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: No, it's good work. We needed another homicide. I mean, we solved three out of the last ten, another unsolved murder will really cement my standing with the Mayor. You got some problem with your fellow detectives? Feel the need to show them up, that it?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: So, it's the Military Police. You think they're a bunch of boobs and are gonna bungle the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: No, sir. But let's not pretend we don't know the Army's real motives for wanting this case.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: When did you discover you had these psychic powers, Detective?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, you don't believe the Army's primary concern will be how this incident reflects on the Army?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: And you see this as a career move, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I don't have a career, sir, I have a job, I take care of my son and I do what I am told. But this boy died in a ditch beside one of our streets. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Someone burned him like a cord of wood, leaving the animals to chew on his remains. With respect, if that was your son just back from Iraq, I think you wouldn't be quite as happy about chucking the case off onto someone else so you would look better come election time.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: That was with respect?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: That was my intent, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll think about it and let you know.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Sir, every moment we lose in this investigation is--

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: Didn't you just say you would do whatever you were told?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I sometimes exaggerate for effect.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: ...How's David?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: Your son.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: He's doing fine, thank you for asking.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: That deadbeat ex of yours ever show up for any of his games?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Luckily David is pretty pathetic at every sport he attempts, so he wants as few people witnessing it as possible. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: That's a shame.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: It's not like he's the boy's father. That moment hangs there a beat longer than it should.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the way I see it, it's the oddballs and misfits who go on to do interesting things with their lives. How many former high school quarterbacks do we roll into the drunk tank every Saturday night? A little misery in school is a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: I was first string quarterback at my high school.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I seem to recall you showing me photographs of such, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: ...You are gonna keep after me about this Deerfield boy, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I think you know what the right thing to do is, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: ...Jesus H. Christ. (picks up phone) Hilary, get me Captain Fenderman at the base. He tosses Sanders a withering look. She tries not to smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock on the door. Hank opens it to reveal GORD BONNER, Mike's squad mate. He seems nervous and overly polite.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Mr. Deerfield?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: I overheard you asking if you could have Mike's Bible. I thought it might bring you some comfort. He hands the Bible to Hank, turns to step away.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Anybody know you took this?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: No, sir. I asked at the visitor center where you were staying and they told me.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (beat) Can I buy you a coffee?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: I really should get back.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: How about a drink? Bonner considers, softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank returns to the pickup with a brown paper bag. He sit and pulls out the fifth of whisky and two Dixie cups, pou

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: To Mike. Hank clinks and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I need to ask you something. I'd like the truth. Was Mike doing drugs?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Doc? I guess.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: No more than other guys. He wasn't like a heavy doper. Hank nods, he doesn't like it but he can understand it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You ever see him hanging out with anyone off the base, maybe Mexicans?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (beat) How you adjusting?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Being back? It hasn't been that long.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You called your parents?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: My mom. My dad and I aren't close. (beat) Did you two talk much?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Sure. (beat) We could have talked more. (beat) Did he ever say anything to you I should know?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: No, sir. I mean, you see a lot of stuff over there; you don't want to talk about it, even with your buddies.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (knows this is true) Yeah. But he did okay, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: He was a first class soldier. You know Mike, loved the Army; he couldn't wait to get over there, save the good guys and hurt the bad guys. (Hank smiles) They shouldn't send heroes to places like Iraq. Everything there is fucked- up. (beat) Before I went, I would never say this; but ask me now? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BONNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They should just nuke it and watch it all turn back to dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see Hank get out of his pickup and head for his door. The camera circles until it finds the phone, its message light blinking. Hank's hand picks it u and punches the  and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hank approaches he can see there is only one person wa on the sidewalk: Joan, sitting on her suitcase. She stand as the truck slows. She opens the door and gets in. Hank drives off without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Hank stand with Kirklander in the corridor outsi the ME's lab, by a viewing window. She nods to Kirklander He raps on the window, the curtain opens. We don't see wh they see, but we see Joan's face. She could never have prepared herself for this.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit down, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: No, no, it's okay. (beat) Is that everything? Is that all of him?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. They must have to keep that room cold. Kirklander knows better than to question the non sequitur He raps on the window for them to close the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It looks cold. Hank nods his thanks to Kirklander. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: My deepest sympathies, ma'am. Hank walks her away down the long corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup pulls to the curb. Other cars drop off passeng Hank looks to her, unsure of what to say. There isn't anything. Joan leans over, gives him a cursory kiss, open the door and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silhouetted against the window, Hank watches the fragment images of war -- searching their frames for meaning, find none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank walks from the motel to the coffee shop next door, a he has done every day since he's been here. This time he' surprised to find the door locked. The JANITOR inside spe through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: Closed. It's Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: ...It is? (beat) Is there someplace close to get something simple? The janitor nods toward the dive across the street. The Checker Box.

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: Checker Box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar is almost empty, it's way too early for crowds. Hank enters, walks to the bar, gets the male BARTENDER's attention. He looks like a former military type.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: What can I do you for?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Can I get a hamburger? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Just cold sandwiches. Chicken or chicken.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Then chicken.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (calling into back) Evie, chicken sandwich. (to Hank) Anything else? Hank slips a photo of Mike out of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You happen to see this soldier in here last weekend?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Sorry. Something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Beer, I guess. Whatever you're pushing. The bartender pulls a glass of beer, gives it to Hank and moves off. Hank drinks like a man who hasn't allowed hims many pleasures. Before he expects it, EVIE, the waitress, shows up behind the bar with his sandwich on a plate. It' pre-made, still in its plastic wrapper. Evie is mid-forti maybe fifty, and topless. Hank freezes.

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: You want mustard or ketchup?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No, thanks, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: Woman stands topless in front of you, "ma'am" could be taken as an insult. (sees photo) This your son?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: (smiles at his discomfort) Handsome boy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm asking if anyone saw him; it would have been last Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: Sorry. All I recognize is the uniform.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thanks. Evie puts the bill down and moves off. Hank pays, takes t sandwich packet and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank picks up his son's Bible and flips through it, stopp at an underlined passage. He reads. Flips to another page finds more underlined passages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders tucks her son into bed.

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: She steps out, leaving David's door open and the hall lig on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders slips the gruesome photos of Mike's dismembered b parts from the file and studies them with a magnifying gl the brightly colored kind that kids use to inspect insect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders knocks on Hank's door; no response. She steps bac looks at his truck and wonders where he's gone. She steps out into the parking lot, looks across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the plate glass window we see Sanders step up. Ha sits at the back in his white T-shirt, waiting for his cl to dry. He sees her approaching and opens the still-spinn dryer, pulls out a cotton shirt and puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Morning. I was wondering if I could ask you a few questions about your son. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I thought it wasn't your case.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Well, it sort of fell back to me.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Isn't that our good fortune.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I was wondering if you knew if your son had any enemies.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You mean other than the thousands of Iraqi and foreign fighters who were trying to kill him up until a couple weeks ago?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Yeah. (beat) That shirt looks like it's still wet.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's dry enough. It obviously isn't, but Hank keeps buttoning and tucking.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Anything bothering him, that you know about?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No. You following up the gang connection?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Do you have a reason to think your son was involved in drugs or gangs?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: When did you last speak to your son?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Why? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (shows him) Capital One faxed me a summary of his recent credit card charges. The day after he returned he bought some tube socks --

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I told him a dozen times those are the worst socks you can buy. No heel, they wear right through.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ...And then that Saturday he bought some chicken.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Does it say what time?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: No. No more charges. We're assuming he was killed sometime Saturday night or Sunday morning. We still haven't found his wallet, but if it was stolen we'd see a lot more charges on it. Stereos, computers, what have you.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You been to the chicken place yet? Sanders looks at him, knows what he is asking, knows she shouldn't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
