dialogues.text: A local chain, full of enlisted men. Sanders waits at the counter for CHUCK the manager, who approaches through the open kitchen. Hank waits behind her, uncomfortable in his damp shirt.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (showing her badge) We're making inquiries about a soldier who was in here a week ago. Sanders shows him a photograph of Mike (not Hank's).

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You're kidding me, right? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (indicates the soldiers) We're a block from the base.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Can you tell from a statement what time he was here?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK

dialogues.text: Close your eyes, feel the wind on your face.

dialogues.text: ...You're supposed to read it to me.

dialogues.text: My mother.

dialogues.text: Before that. You're named after King David. Your mother never tell you that? (David shakes his head) Yeah, that figures.

dialogues.text: listening from the kitchen reacts, but chooses not to interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There were two armies assembled, the Israelites and the Philistines; they were both on hills, with the Valley of Elah between them. That's a place in Palestine. You know where that is? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: David shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. Anyway, the Philistines had a champion, a giant named Goliath.

dialogues.text: There's a robot named Goliath.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: This wasn't him. Anyway, every day for 40 days, Goliath strode out into the field and challenged somebody from the other side to fight him, and nobody would. The strongest and bravest warriors that the king had were all too scared.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why didn't they just shoot him?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: They didn't have guns. (beat) They had arrows, but there are rules to combat. You don't shoot somebody who is challenging you to fight with a sword. So, this kid, not much older than you, he comes delivering bread. And he says to the king, "I'll fight Goliath."

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: True story. So, the king dressed David in his own armor, but it was much too big and heavy. So, David takes it off. He looks around and finds five smooth stones, about yay big. He steps into the field, with his slingshot in his hand. And Goliath comes running, yelling, this horrible scream. And David lets fly the stone. And hits him in the forehead. Cracks his skull. And Goliath falls down, dead.

You know how much nerve that took? A few more steps and Goliath would have crushed him. And then he threw the rock. That's how you fight monsters. Lure 'em close to you, look 'em in the eye and smack 'em down.

dialogues.text: You fight a lot of monsters?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ..You win?

dialogues.text: If I didn't, I would have been crushed, right? David sees the logic. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay then. You go to sleep. He turns off the light and leaves, closing the door behin him, casting the room into darkness.

dialogues.text: --What?

dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ...Now you want me to guess.

dialogues.speaker: LONG
dialogues.text: We found a hooker on 10 Mile Road and she blew all four of us.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Do you remember her name? at her, the question being ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: LONG
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, why didn't you say this when you were questioned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We realize she addressed that question to Gordon Bonner.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Because we didn't think Mike would want his parents to know.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ...You didn't want his father to know he got a blow job?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: And was buying drugs. I wouldn't want somebody telling my parents.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, what was the fight about?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Mike was in some dark mood, I don't know why. Then he started saying nasty things to that stripper.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Just stuff I'm not going to repeat. The woman's a stripper, not something on your shoe.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Out in the parking lot, Penning said Mike came at you swinging.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Might have, don't recall. We thought finding him some sort of sex would calm him down. But not Mike.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You didn't like him much, did you? You got in a lot of fights.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: There were people I liked better. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, what was different about that night? Was it just that you hada knife?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: I want to kill someone, I don't need a knife, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, you never killed anyone with a knife.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Don't believe I said that.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: But I guess in Iraq things were different. Someone makes you mad, you could deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: You lost me.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: It's a different world. You have power.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: You've obviously never been in the Army.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You have weapons, authority; you put men face down in the dirt, step on their backs, kick in their doors. Someone comes running at you, you kill him. You have to, right? Guy could have a bomb or a gun, you kill him first.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: You make the call.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Woman walks toward you screaming, won't stop, does she have a bomb? Not a lot of time to think. You react or die. Ever have to stab someone?

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: If I did it wouldn't be your business. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kirklander switches off the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You're there one day, here the next; somebody comes charging at me, I'd be reaching for a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: (to Sanders) Did you notice the interview was over? (to Bonner) Let's go. Sanders continues as she walks them out into:

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm finished. I'm just glad none of that stuff bothered you. Because, I tell you, I saw my father come home with things he did that he couldn't live with. It pretty much destroyed him.

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: Your father? What was he in, Panama? You have no idea what we did over there. And we did it for you.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: For me??

dialogues.speaker: BONNER
dialogues.text: So, if I were you, I'd just say "thanks," leave it at that and kiss my ass. And he walks off. Kirklander stays with Sanders.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: You happy, or do you want to convene a war crimes tribunal? Sanders turns on her heels and storms back into --

dialogues.speaker: THE INTERVIEW ROOM
dialogues.text: -- and gathers up her stuff. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I want the clothes they were wearing and I want to take full body photographs for cuts and bruises. She heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: You can have the clothes. But you may want to glance at this. He hands her the manilla envelope. The way he said it mak her look at it with curiosity. She opens it and slides an 8x10 photo out -- black and white, a frame from a surveil camera posted at the guard gate: Bonner's car, Bonner dri Penning and Long the passengers. The time and date are stamped large, among other information. 1:26 AM. She understands the significance.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Still want them?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (refuses to admit defeat) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks on the computer and plays a video clip again -- sporadic images, mostly black. A prisoner on the floor of a humvee. A SCREAM. Mike is saying something we can't make out. Another SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Leave him alone! It ends frozen on Ortiez, who stares hatefully at the cam The phone rings, startling him.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (phone filter) Mr. Deerfield? My names is Jennifer Lopez. I heard you were looking for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank waits uneasily at a nurses' station. A moment later nurse steps in from the adjoining ward. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Deerfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse leads Hank through the HALL and into a double r where JENNIFER LOPEZ sits sideways on her bed, her back t Hank and the nurse. A MEDICAL TECHNICIAN is helping Ms. Lopez with something we can't see.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Here's your guest.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: I'll be two secs. The nurse exits. Hank realizes the technician is fitting Jennifer with a prosthetic arm.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think it just needs to be tighter. The technician nods and moves off with the arm.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nods toward the chair) Please, sit. Jennifer throws her leg back onto the bed and Hank sees t her other leg is missing. Hank tries not to look.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You left a message on my Uncle Jay's voicemail. I guess you found out how many Lopezes there are in the phone book.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: I read what happened to Mike. I'm really sorry. He was a great guy.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Did you serve together?

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: No. I'ma reservist. And I don't think you can call what I did "serving." This happened my first day in Iraq. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We had no doors on our vehicle, driver pulled to the shoulder, IED exploded. Thank God I had my face turned away from it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Mike and I met two years ago, (smiles) --at a bar. I'd had a little too much to drink and Mike saw this guy pawing me and just laid him out. Bam. He took me home in a cab, didn't even try to kiss me good night. (smiles again) After that, we went out all the time, until he left. He was very sweet. (beat ) He called me when he got back.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (now interested) He did.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Yeah, he came to see me that Friday. She lets that hang.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Did he say anything? You know, anything that could help me find out who did this to him?

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: No. I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: How did he seem?

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: ...I'm not sure what I should say. I mean, he was a great guy. And I want to remember him...I want you to remember him that way. She pauses. Hank knows not to say anything -- an old investigator's trick. She finally continues. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He wasn't.... There was something in him I'd never seen before. I don't think I should be telling you this.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: When he saw me. He laughed. I mean, at first I thought, "great" -- I mean, I am so sick of the sympathetic looks, laughing was sort of refreshing. So I laughed, too. Then he said...not to worry; the parts he was interested in still worked. I didn't know what to say. Hank takes this in. Jennifer tries to undo the damage.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sure it was just...I don't know what it was. (beat) He talked about you a lot, you know. Before he left. He was really worried he'd let you down. What you thought of him was everything. (beat) I'm sorry I said those things. Hank is overwhelmed. He wants to reach out and touch her hand, but She nods. can't.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I want to apologize on his behalf.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: You don't have to, I'm sure he didn't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I appreciate the sacrifice you made for our country. Hank steps INTO THE HALL. His way is blocked by an approaching gurney, another amputee. He takes another route through the ward. He can't help glancing into the rooms, seeing all the young wounded and limbless patients  85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank searches for his pickup in the parking lot, but can' seem to recall where he left it. The camera rises to reve Hank lost in a sea of cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders sits studying the files that Kirklander gave her, finding nothing. She looks up and sees Hank sitting quiet in the waiting area. Gone is his earlier arrogance, he appears almost broken. She stands and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You want to come in? He stands and follows her to her desk, where they sit.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were right, they couldn't have done it. They were with Mike at the chicken shack at one. She hands him the folded page that Kirklander gave her.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bonner, Penning and Long arrived back at base twenty minutes later. He looks at the page: a black and white frame from a secu camera at the Ft. Rudd guard gate -- Penning, Long and Bo in a car returning to the base. The time stamp reads 01:2

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The field where we found Mike's remains is a half hour away. They couldn't have even driven there in time, never mind anything else.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: They left him there alone, at the chicken shack?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ...They say Mike wanted to buy drugs.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That's why they lied?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: And they say they were with a prostitute earlier, Mike included. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands 86.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: They didn't think I'd seen soldiers using prostitutes? (Sanders shrugs) They have no idea where Mike went when they left him, who he met?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: No. (re: files on her desk) I have statements from every other man in his squad....

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: May I see them? them over, he leafs through them.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: If they're to be believed, no one else saw him after dinner time. Nugent approaches with two evidence bags, stuffed full of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: Lab says no traces of blood on the clothes or their belongings.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Did you look at those clothes? One of the shirts still has crease marks where it came off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (still reading reports) Clothes are cheap on the base. First thing you do when you get back is toss every stitch you took with you. There are nine men in an infantry squad. Sanders tries to comprehend the apparent non-sequitur.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: .+.Yes?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: They lost one man in Iraq, there should still be seven statements. There are only six. He hands the files to Nugent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: So, one of them is on leave.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: The day I arrived the Sergeant told me all his men were back from liberty. A beat, then Sanders pulls out the list Kirklander gave h

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (to Nugent) Read the names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At NUGENT'S DESK, Nugent on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: This is Fred Gainley at the Buxton Sheriff's office. You missing a man? Because I have Robert Ortiez here on a Drunk and Disorderly who says he's one of yours.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. CARNELLI
dialogues.text: Thanks, I'll send someone over to get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nugent hangs up, turns to Sanders and Hank.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: He's AWOL.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Check for priors and warrants. And see if he owns a car. Nugent types. ROBERT ORTIEZ' criminal record appears on t screen, his arrest photo has villain written all over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders speaks with detective Manny NUNEZ, narcotics and gang division. Hank waits at a distance, listening.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUNEZ
dialogues.text: Local boy. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUNEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I first arrested Bobby Ortiez when he was fourteen for drug trafficking. He got bail and the witness disappeared. Couple of misdemeanors after that, then a year and a half ago we liked him for drug smuggling. Suddenly he gets patriotic and joins up.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: How the hell did they let him in the Army? Detective Nugent enters with a sheet of paper, passing Ha

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUNEZ
dialogues.text: No felony convictions. And they've been lowering the standards every month since this thing started.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: He has a 1999 Chevrolet Malibu registered in his name.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: What color?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: (checks) Blue. Sanders shares a look with Hank.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Not enough for a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: He's AWOL.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Army can go after him, we can't.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: (reading) Four unpaid parking tickets?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Try Judge Osorio. Nugent leaves to do so. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Nunez) Any idea where he'd go to ground?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUNEZ
dialogues.text: (grabbing his jacket) Finding Bobby was never the problem.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Hank waits as they head out with shotguns, pulling on ves Sanders pauses briefly.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Go to your motel. I will call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunez's unmarked car pulls out of the parking lot, Sander and Nugent right behind them. As they disappear down the street, Hank's pickup pulls out and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nugent assumes backup position at his vehicle. Sanders ta the side door. She notes Ortiez's blue Chevy in the cover carpark. Nunez and his partner creep up the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: WITH HANK
dialogues.text: His pickup cruises up in time to see:

dialogues.speaker: NUNEZ AND HIS PARTNER
dialogues.text: -- bang on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUNEZ
dialogues.text: Police Department, open the door! They take the door down with a ram. Nunez rushes past Cho smoking dope, as his partner holds them at gunpoint.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: -- is the first to see...

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ ON THE ROOF
dialogues.text: -- bursting out from a trap door and running along the ri toward the attached garage.  90.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Sanders hears feet clattering on the roof, spots Ortiez j as he jumps off into the alley and disappears. Sanders bo for the back yard, clambering over junk and climbing the back fence. Nunez slams open the back door and gives chase.

dialogues.speaker: FROM A BLOCK AWAY
dialogues.text: Hank watches the game unfold, sees Nugent run back to his vehicle, wills him to do the smart thing:

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Take the street, take the street -- Nugent wheels into the alley.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christ. Hank drops the truck into gear and rolls down the street, turning the corner and paralleling the alley.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK ALLEY
dialogues.text: We can see why catching Ortiez isn't easy -- this kid run and climbs fences like a goat on steroids. He bounds a fe and jumps into a backyard. Sanders scrambles after him, but stays in the alley. Nugent swerves through the twisting dirt alley, swerving right before breaking hard at a dead end. Nunez comes around the corner. Sanders screams that he's "in the yards." Nunez jumps the fence and pursues as... Ortiez leaps from one yard to the next. Nunez tries a fence and misses, slamming back onto his as Sanders keeps running...but she can see Ortiez is getting away.

dialogues.speaker: OUT ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: Hank cruises, scanning the houses and side yards until he glimpses Ortiez. Hank sees where Ortiez is going to cut into the open. He stomps on the accelerator. Ortiez burst out onto the street. Hank catches up to him and swings op his driver's door, slamming Ortiez to the pavement. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hank grabs his metal trucker's flashlight and leaps out b Ortiez can scramble to his feet. Ortiez's knife appears o of nowhere, but Hank catches him with a kick to the gut t puts him back down. Still reeling, Ortiez lunges, but Han catches him square in the jaw with the flashlight. Ortiez hits the pavement and Hank pummels him viciously.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Fucking wetbacks; it's always knives, isn't it? You enjoy cutting him up? Did you? Sanders arrives and tries to pull him off. Reacting instinctively, Hank elbows her in the face, breaking her nose and sending her sprawling. He doesn't even glance ba he just keeps releasing his fury on Ortiez's bloody face. Nunez arrives a heartbeat later, aiming his weapon.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUNEZ
dialogues.text: Let him go! Stop! But he doesn't. Nugent runs up and pulls Hank off, rollin him to the ground; Hank struggles with Nugent, trying to back at Ortiez.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: Hey! HEY! What the hell are you doing?! Hank comes to his senses and stops struggling. Sanders struggles to her feet, holding her spurting nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank opens his eyes. He sits cuffed to a wooden bench. He looks down at his hands, cut and swollen. He glances through the open door and sees Ortiez being released from a holding cell, into the custody of two bur MPs. They head for the exit, meaning they're going to hav to pass Hank. Hank tugs on the chain that binds him as th near.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What was it? You wanted him to carry drugs for you and he wouldn't do it? You afraid he was going to tell on you? That it, Chico? That did it. Ortiez jerks to a stop, face to face with Ha leans in close to his ear and whispers: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be funny if the devil looked just like you? The MPs get him moving again. Hank calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Come back here, you wetback prick, I'll show you what the devil looks like.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: (laughs him off) Fuck you, man. Ortiez disappears around the corner with his guards. He turns and sees Sanders approaching, her nose swollen, a b aid over the cut.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I see you cracked him wide open.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Hold out your hands.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to hit you.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: That what passes for an apology in your world? (as she uncuffs him) He isn't pressing charges. You're damn lucky I feel pity for you or I'd be doing it myself.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Keep it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Is anyone going to question him?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I questioned him, they questioned him, we searched his house, there is no evidence that he had anything to do with it! Hank doesn't know what to say. Sanders turns on her heel and walks off.  93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank lies awake in his soiled white T-shirt, staring at t ceiling. The sheets are half off the bed. The room is unrecognizably messy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm clock reads 10:18 AM. Hank wakes to a knock on the door. He opens it to Sanders.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Something's happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders and Lt. Kirklander stand over the gurney.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: We found him hanging in his room. A morgue technician pulls back the sheet to reveal Gordon Bonner's horribly discolored face, his neck scarred and r

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Did he leave a note?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirklander opens a small manilla envelope and tips the contents into Hank's hand. It's a watch, circa 1950.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: My father gave it to me when I went to Vietnam. I gave it to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: It was in Bonner's pants pocket. The thought strikes Hank as amazing.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: ...He was carrying it? He didn't leave a note -- he just put it in his pocket and then hung himself?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's as close as we're going to get to a confession. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Confession. Hank exits, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Bonner's car; what color is it?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: Blue. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank follows Sanders to her vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You don't kill someone for no reason. That watch isn't proof of anything.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You think your son would have given it to him?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It could have been planted on his body!

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, why did he kill himself, Hank?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I don't know! But tell me how he killed Mike! He had an alibi, he was back at the base! When did he do it? Why did he do it?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ...I don't know, Hank. I'm sorry. She climbs into her Taurus, exhausted. Hank shakes his he and walks off to his pickup. Sanders' cell phone rings. She answers it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nugent on the other end of the phone. He doesn't want to have this conversation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NUGENT
dialogues.text: ...Remember the woman with the dead dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders comes around the corner and steps out onto the st of identical mobile homes, lit by flashers from police vehicles. Hastily dressed neighbors stand across the stre from a home that lies at the eye of the storm. As she walks toward it, she notices a muscular man in his late 20s, close cropped hair, sitting cuffed in the back seat of a squad car. Several officers stand by it, smokin and talking. Everyone shows up for a murder. Sanders lifts the crime scene tape and walks through the open front door, which boasts an Army service sticker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders weaves through the milling officers. Detective wa catches her eye -- it's the first sympathetic look he's e given her. She keeps moving, finding Hodge in the hallway outside th bathroom. There's water all over the bathroom floor. Smal feet poke over the edge of the bathtub. He speaks kindly.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE HODGE
dialogues.text: We drained it. Sanders steps forward until she can see Angie, the woman complained about her husband drowning her dog, lying in t tub, her clothes clinging to her. Sanders squats beside the tub for fear of falling. She as the question she doesn't want answered.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Where's the boy?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE HODGE
dialogues.text: He wasn't home, thank God. He's at his grandparents.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: That's good. She touches Angie's hand.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's good.  96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank sits on the bare, stained mattress, phone to his ear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan sits in the kitchen, staring out the back door. She makes no move to answer the ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is busy and yet remarkably quiet. Sanders sits a her desk, going through her phone log and losing herself the minutiae of her job. The civilian worker from the fro desk drops off a Fed Ex envelope and offers Sanders a sympathetic smile. Sanders opens it and goes through the contents with little interest. It's a credit card stateme with hard receipts attached -- various purchases Mike mad including the tube socks and the chicken. She flips throu them and then tosses them in her out basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank sits slumped in a chair in the corridor, waiting. An OFFICER steps out of one of the cubicles. Hank stands as approaches, hands him a clipboard to sign.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: The remains will be shipped this afternoon, if you'd please just check the address of the funeral home.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's correct.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: And, I'm afraid we have to keep the skull. Until the case is officially closed. I'm sorry. (hands him carbon receipt) If I can be of any other help, please let me know. Hank watches the young officer walk off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank closes the driver door and cranks the key. The batte is dead. He sees he's left his headlights on, stabs the switch back in place and gets out.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank walks along the corridor, no one around. He stops at an open door, looks in. It's Penning. Hank thinks about walking away, but then Penning turns.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: . Sir?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: ...You got jumper cables?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penning opens the hood of his brown Nissan and attaches t leads. Hank hits the ignition and the truck comes to life Penning walks to the driver's window.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: I wanted to say how sorry I am, what happened to Mike. And I need to apologize, for lying, about not seeing him that night. I just thought that, if I were Mike, I wouldn't want my parents to know. Hank nods.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You have a cigarette? Penning pops out one and Hank accepts it. They light up.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think Bonner killed him?

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: No. I don't know. I don't understand any of this.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What would he have against my boy?

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Nothing. I'm sorry. (a moment ) Mike tell you much about Bosnia?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Some. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: We seemed to always pull sentry duty, freezing our asses off. He used to try and convince me of the craziest things.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Try to get you to wear pantyhose?

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Did he tell you??

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I told him. Cuts the cold like nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: So he wasn't lying??

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You just gotta make sure you aren't shot while wearing a pair, or you'll never live it down. Penning has to laugh. Hank smiles for the first time in many days. Then his thoughts drift back to his dead son.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: It's fucked up, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is. And then a thought strikes Hank, and he looks at Penning. It is clear from his expression that Hank now knows somet we don't; something terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank downloads a video and plays it. Black punctuated by occasional flash of an image; the audio comes in and out. Someone is whimpering, pleading in Arabic. We see a flash of his face: a bound IRAQI PRISONER with a bag over his h lying on the floor of the moving High Back Humvee between the feet of the men in Mike's squad. Mike is just off scr sitting over him, apparently holding the camera. Screen goes BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where does it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: A SCREAM,
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, asshole! (to prisoner) It's okay, I'll help you. He's not going to hurt you again. FRAGMENTED IMAGES - Mike jabs his boot into the prisoner' wound. The prisoner SCREAMS. Mike pretends it was Ortiez.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Leave him alone! ORTIEZ sitting beside Mike, LAUGHING, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (to Ortiez) You fucking pervert

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: (laughing) Fuck you, man. The CAMERA SWINGS BACK to the man on the floor as Mike ja his boot into the prisoner's wound. The prisoner SCREAMS, the pain searing. Mike keeps probing, torturing the priso out of sport. The camera tilting up to Mike's face for th first time as he turns off the camera and the image freez HANK sits there, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders drops a file in her out basket, puts her jacket o to leave, sits and picks up her purse from under her desk But she can't seem to stand. She looks around the room, then at her brimming out basket. Something makes her reconsider a document in there. She slides out the credit card statement and flips through it, wondering what bothe her about it. She stops at the chicken receipt and then looks back at t tube sock and other receipts -- the signature for the chi is different than the others. She moves quickly to the file cabinet and jerks it open, finds the original statements that the men made about the whereabouts. She checks the signatures, Bonner, Long and Penning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank packs his bag.  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders slaps Penning's statement down on the desk, under bright lamp, beside the receipt. She compares the signatu Key letters in both are exactly the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banging. Hank opens the door. Sanders has to stop herself from commenting on how awful he looks. She hands him a file folder with a credit card receipt cl to the cover.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Tell me that's your son's signature on his credit card receipt.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's not.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: We just assumed Mike was there. It's Penning's signature. Three meals: Penning, Long and Bonner.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: They drive toward the base in silence. Sanders glances at Hank, tries to read him; can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Taurus idles in a parking space near the guard gate. Sanders waits impatiently beside the car, staring at the guards in the kiosk, one reading a comic book.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. She looks to Hank, stone-faced in the passenger seat. She would have expected rage, not fatalism. She gets it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You knew. How? Hank doesn't answer. The phone in the guard booth rings, the guard answers it, hangs up and approaches. He hands h back the warrants.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you waiting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sure. Sanders races onto the base, ignoring the speed bumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank waits in the hall as Sanders steps into Kirklander's office and drops the two warrants on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Penning and Long. I want them now. The door closes behind her.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: I can't give them to you.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Damn right you can and you will.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: They're under arrest. Corporal Penning's come forward. He's implicated Specialists Long and Bonner.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: (gets it) You son of a bitch. You went to him with a deal. Didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: He'll do serious time.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: How much?.... HOW MUCH TIME?!

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: ...AS much as I could get.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Well, luckily that means nothing to me. These are warrants, we have jurisdiction and you are compelled to produce these men. I want them now.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: I'm not the only one who made a deal. Sanders gets a bad feeling. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My CO talked to yours. One less headache. It's out of our hands. (beat) I'm sorry. Sanders takes this in, looks back to Hank, waiting in the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I want to hear the confession.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: Long isn't speaking, I'll get you Penning's statement.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: No, I want to hear it from his lips. (nodding toward Hank) And I want him present.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: That's not going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: How many soldiers leave the base every night to visit a bar, havea drink or two?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: I know you're feeling burned....

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: What would you guess? On a weekend, what, seven or eight thousand soldiers? I tell you what I can do. I can sit in my car outside of any of your entrances, pull over every vehicle returning to base and arrest every soldier whose blood alcohol is one one thousandths over the legal limit. How many men do you think that would be? And how many do you think would have a little weed stashed under their seat?

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: And how long do you think it would be until you're fired? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Well, I'd be doing it on my own time, and we have a pretty good union, so I'd say four or five weeks. How many DUI cases do you think I can make in a month? You want to find out? Silence. Kirklander finally picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank and Sanders sit on one side of the table, Penning an JAG attorney sit on the other. Kirklander stands in the background.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: We leave the strip club and we think that Mike and Bonner have cooled down. I mean they could be like that, laughing one minute and fighting the next. Anyway, we're in the car and Mike's all pissy. And Bonner starts needling him. Saying shit.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: I don't know, like what a good driver Mike is, stuff that makes no sense. Bonner has enough and pulls over and they go at each other again. Long is yelling for them to cut it out so we can go home and Mike starts cursing him, too, and I look down and I'm stabbing him.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You are. She throws a look to Kirklander, who can't hold her glanc

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, he always had to push things too far, you know? What's making me madder is that he is just standing there, not fighting back, like some sort of weird macho thing.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Your friends didn't try and stop you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: I think they were sort of stunned. They're yelling. And then Mike falls down. And he's dead. And Long says, "Christ, what do we do now?" It was Bonner's idea to chop him up. He used to work in a butcher shop; knew how to work the knife around the joints; made it easier. (beat) We were going to bury the parts, but it was getting late. And we hadn't eaten.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You were hungry?

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: Starving. So, we stopped at the chicken shack. Sanders tries not to react.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ask me why, I don't know. I liked Mike, we all did. (beat) But on another night? That could have been Mike with the knife and me in the field. I think Mike was the smart one. I think he could see. Penning starts to be overcome by his emotions. To Hank:

dialogues.speaker: PENNING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am truly sorry, sir. I'm sorry for your loss. Hank fights the urge to leap across the table and strangl him.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I saw a video Mike shot, him in the back of a Humvee. It looked like he was torturing a prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: PENNING
dialogues.text: (has to smile) We arrested some hajji, he's wounded. We're riding along and Mike pretends he's a medic, sticks his hand in the guy's wound, asks "Does that hurt?" (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PENNING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Hajji screams "yeah-yeah-yeah." Mike says "How about here?" (laughs despite himself) It was pretty funny. It became a thing with him. That's how he got the name "Doc." It was just a way to cope. We all did stupid things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank steps out into the night air, trying not to show tha his world is crumbling around him.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND HIM
dialogues.text: Kirklander steps up to Sanders.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KIRKLANDER
dialogues.text: When I made the deal, I didn't know it was Penning who did the stabbing. I read it wrong. She nods, understanding; she would have been fooled, too. She glances toward Hank, dreading having to talk to him. Kirklander heads back to his office and Sanders has no ch but to walk to the exit and join Hank.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I'll get the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights are on. Sanders pulls up, confused to see another car in the drive. Buchwald steps out, envelope in hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: I wanted to drop these by. I was going to knock, but I didn't want to spook your sitter.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: And you thought a stranger sitting out here staring at the house would make her feel more secure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: They're for a Lobos game. That's football. Good game, Lobos against the Utah Utes.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: No kidding. The Utes.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: Thought it was worth a shot, before you turn the boy against the game forever.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF BUCHWALD
dialogues.text: You did good police work.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Figured that's what they were for. Sanders exits into the house. Buchwald backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parking lot lies quiet, one car departing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank packs up the laptop and Mike's photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An NCO waits as Hank packs Mike's few articles into his duffel. He hands it off to the NCO as a NEW RECRUIT, in h Class A's, steps in, carrying his duffel and paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: NEW RECRUIT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Hank takes this in, then looks down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Which is Private Ortiez's room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank appears at the open door, sees Ortiez inside packing his belongings. Ortiez notices Hank standing there.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You have a minute? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ortiez isn't quite sure how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to apologize to you.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: Damn straight you do.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: You got some serious issues, man.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's true. A moment. Hank holds up a fresh fifth of whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ortiez drinks from the bottle and passes it to Hank. He a Hank sit on the low wall under the overhang at the barrac watching a sergeant drill his recruits in the field.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: I got an honorable discharge, if you can believe it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's the Army, I'd believe anything.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: (watching troops) I hated it over there. Sleep in fucking tents, no toilets, no showers, no toilet paper, gotta use your hand -- and you never know where the bullet is coming from. I couldn't wait to get out. And after two weeks here, all I want to do is go back, cause somehow that makes sense. How fucked is that? They sit there a moment. Hank hands Ortiez one of Mike's photos: the body on the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know what this is? (no answer) Mike took it and emailed it to me. Why would he do that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ
dialogues.text: (beat) I don't know what anybody told you. (Hank waits him out) There were standing orders. You're driving in convoy, someone or something gets in front of your vehicle, you do not stop. You stop, shitheads pop up with RPGs and kill you all dead. (beat) First week in Iraq, we're driving down range, six of us in back, you can't see squat back there. Doc hits something. We hear it thump around underneath. He stops, gets out; drives on. Not a word. Later, some guys said we hit a kid, I don't believe it. You ask me, it was a dog. We killed a dog. And Hank can see how hard Ortiez wants to believe that.

dialogues.speaker: ORTIEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't know what that is. No fucking idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank opens his driver's door and throws the duffel in bef him, slides in and starts the engine before he closes the truck door. He stares out through the windshield and sees

dialogues.speaker: BAGHDAD STREET
dialogues.text: A kid runs into the middle of the street, between vehicle picks up a soccer ball and turns to look toward the camer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike panics, Bonner urges him to speed up, Mike steps on accelerator.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: The Humvee hits the boy with the ball. The only sound we hear is the thud, and then the body tumbling under the vehicle's undercarriage.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE HIGH BACK HUMVEE
dialogues.text: Mike drives on a moment, betraying no emotion. Then brake  109.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: Mike steps out and walks back toward the small body that lies on the side of the road. Bonner gets out and yells a him. Mike stops. He sees people running toward the body, from a nearby house. Ortiez parts the tarp and peers out from the back. Mike lifts his phone, composes the shot, and takes a pict of the body. Mike turns and walks back. Bonner hesitates, obviously unnerved by the sight of the body. They return to the vehicle, step in and tugs closed the door.

dialogues.speaker: BACK WITH HANK
dialogues.text: The images are too much to bear. He pulls his door closed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders sits with Hank.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: So, my son has been driving me crazy ever since you came over. He wants a slingshot. Hank smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guess it could be worse, could be a bee-bee gun.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It was Mike's favorite story, too. He tries not to show her the pain that is threatening to overwhelm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders walks Hank to his pickup. He gets in, looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thank you. She nods. Hank drives off without looking back.  110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank carries his overnight case toward the dark house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark. Hank turns on the light above the stove Mike's package sits on the counter, opened. He peels back the paper to reveal a tightly folded flag. An envelope si atop addressed to "Dad." Hank finds a photo inside, Mike and his squad mates stretching the flag, jerry-rigged to pole over their humvee, smiling broadly. Hank turns the photo over. It is inscribed: "For Dad, love Mike." Hank turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank sits on the edge of the bed, the phone to his ear. Joan sleeps on her side.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Something happened, Dad. Something bad. And then we hear Mike start to cry. Hank is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Oh for Christ's sake. (beat) Is there anyone there with you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, I'm alone.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: IN BAGHDAD
dialogues.text: Mike on the payphone, trying to keep it together.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You be safe, son. Stay safe.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You too, Dad. Mike hangs up and walks away to join his unit outside.  141.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Hank hangs up. We cut to the doorway and see

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: standing there, fully dressed. And now he weeps, knowing let his son down when the boy needed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the dark room and the neatly made bed.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: steps up behind him, rubs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: He asked for my help. I didn't even listen. He wants to say more, but doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank picks up an empty frame and slips Mike's photograph back into it -- him in his dress uniform, now considerabl worn. He replaces it on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders sits on the bed with her son, telling him a story

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Every day Goliath would walk out into the valley and challenge someone, anyone, to fight him. No one would. Until David showed up and said, "I'll fight him." So, the king dressed David in his own armor, but it was too big and heavy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why would the king let him fight a giant? He was just a boy.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: I don't know, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You think he was scared? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: Hank EXT. Hank Hank Hank Hank flag

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: David? Yeah, I think he would have been really scared.

dialogues.speaker: DEERFIELD HOME
dialogues.text: picks up the opened parcel from the counter.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: attaches the flag. Juan watches Hank raise it.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: (re: flag) Looks really old.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's been well used. duct tapes the line firmly to the pole.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: And I shouldn't take it down at night? hands Juan all the bills in his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No, you leave it just like that.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN
dialogues.text: That's much easier. nods and walks off, and now we see the tattered battle flapping in the wind atop the pole. Upside down. The End
